item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Will Run At 4K60 On PS5 Pro
item.content:encoded:
Resident Evil Requiem launches on February 27, and Capcom is letting players know what they can expect if they have Sony’s best PlayStation console.

In a post on the Japanese PlayStation Blog, game director Akishi Nakanishi discussed how Resident Evil Requiem will play on the PlayStation 5 Pro (PS5 Pro).

PS5 Pro Gets An Optimized Experience

Nakanishi revealed that PS5 Pro users will be able to turn ray tracing on and off. With ray tracing turned on, players will be able to play Resident Evil Requiem at 4K resolution at 60 frames per second (FPS).

Should you be on a monitor that supports higher frames, you’ll be able to take advantage of rates up to 120 FPS. Nakanishi said that there will be an average of 90 FPS on the system.

What Is Resident Evil Requiem?

Resident Evil Requiem is the ninth mainline game in the long running horror franchise. The new game follows FBI analyst Grace Ashcroft as she’s tasked with investigating a number of strange deaths at the Wrenwood Hotel in Racoon City. It’s the same location where her mother, Alyssa Ashcroft, was killed eight years prior.

It also seems the return of Leon Kennedy who has to look into incidents that have been linked to scientist Victor Gideon. The game’s events are set roughly 30 years after Resident Evil 3: Nemesis.

The game releases on February 27 for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, Nintendo Switch 2, and PC.

What platform are you planning to play Resident Evil Requiem? Leave your thoughts down in the comments below, and join the discussion in the official Insider Gaming Discord.

For more news, check out when WWE 2K26 will release and some of the first systems confirmed for the game. And for even more Insider Gaming delivered directly to your inbox, sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: No, Dr Disrespect Was Not Invited To Play Highguard
item.content:encoded:
The internet’s social corners are ablaze following a recent claim from Dr Disrespect that he was invited to play Highguard alongside Wildlight Entertainment in Los Angeles. The ‘Two Time’ posted an image on social media of an ID card from the recent event and directly stated he’d taken ‘the Lambo to LA’ to play Highguard.

Even though it took literal seconds to figure out Dr Disrespect’s image was a fake, likely manufactured by the same folks who make his streamer art, some have boycotted Highguard because of this impossible collaboration.

Dr Disrespect Fakes Highguard Invite

On January 24, Dr Disrespect posted an image on social media of his desk, some streaming and gaming equipment, and an ID card that marked him as an attendee to the recent Highguard event in Los Angeles.

It was a staging ground for Wildlight to showcase the all-new shooter in full to a wide audience of streamers, creators, pro gamers, and influencers, and some folks believed that Dr Disrespect also went.

When the image cropped up on social media, it took some who were in attendance mere seconds to debunk the image, simply by showing their own, legitimate passes, and pointing out the inaccuracies. But that wasn’t enough for the detritus of those social circles that avoid using logic and reasoning to solve something cryptic.

Unfortunately, many took to those same social circles to slam Wildlight for associating with a creator with Dr Disrespect’s reputation. Anyone even remotely interested in the creator space knows about the recent controversies that the scandalous streamer found himself embroiled in over the last couple of years.

Now, the Creator Manager for Highguard at Wildlight Entertainment, Chin, has posted a definitive comment on social media, further debunking the image:

Hey there! I’m Chin, the Creator Manager for Highguard / Wildlight and I can confirm DDR was not invited to any Highguard event past or present, and the badge was not an official badge.

So, no, Dr Disrespect did not jet off to Los Angeles to play Highguard with everyone else. He is streaming the game as this article is being written, but that’s the closest to it he’ll ever be.

Did you fall for Dr Disrespect’s tricks? Let us know on the Insider Gaming Discord server if you’ve learnt the error of your ways.

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that Highguard hit 500,000 viewers in under an hour

Grant's adoration for gaming started on the Amstrad CPC in 1996. Now, he's a multi-platform expert gamer with a deep love for the industry, a passion for esports, and more…

More from Grant Taylor-Hill

item.title: Highguard Battle Pass, Explained—How To Get Free War Chest
item.content:encoded:
You can’t have a new live-service game without a Battle Pass, and Highguard doesn’t advertise a properly labeled Battle Pass, to an extent. This guide covers how to get a free War Chest and how it relates to Highguard.

Everyone gets the ick at the mention of a Battle Pass due to the negative connotations. However, if something is free to play, it’s going to have a Battle Pass, and Highguard complicates things with its War Chest system.

Does Highguard Have A Battle Pass?

Highguard has a fully fledged Battle Pass system under the guise of a War Chest.

Same thing, different name. A War Chest is the name for the game’s Battle System. It has the Pages system that Fortnite and others have adopted in recent years, allowing you to have more freedom in how you accumulate Highguard rewards.

Each reward requires so much Highguard currency, and they include the usual slew of live-service cosmetics: Skins, weapons makeovers, customizable player profile items, and more. Subsequent War Chests will presumably require real money or acquired in-game currency, but not the first one.

How To Claim Free War Chest In Highguard

You need to go into the Highguard Store, click on War Chest, and claim your free Battle Pass.

Here’s a quick step-by-step guide on what to do:

  1. Load up Highuard.
  2. Go to the main menu.
  3. Make sure you’re on the tabs at the top.
  4. Cycle across to Store.
  5. Click on Inspect War Chest in the corner.
  6. Claim the War Chest.
  7. You now have a free Battle Pass for Highguard Episode 1.

The first War Chest has a total of 44 items to claim. Goodies vary in terms of rarity, and they’re spread across ‘4 Chapters.’ You need to play matches and rack up a serious amount of Vigil Tokens—which are used in exchange for the rewards found in the War Chest.

It’s expected that future War Chests will follow a similar format, unless there’s stern opposition from the Highguard community.

Will you endeavour to complete the first-ever Highguard War Chest, AKA Battle Pass? Or do you think the rewards are a complete waste of time and not worth the effort? Head to the Insider Gaming Discord Server and let us know how’d you rate the content on a scale of 1-10.

Make sure you check out the Highguard 2026 Roadmap, featuring all Highguard episode content, as well as Highguard’s Crossplay status.

item.title: WWE 2K26 Releases In March, Will Be Available On Nintendo Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
The marketing train is in full swing for WWE 2K26. Not only have various editions of the game been revealed in recent days, but it’s now known when the game will release as well as some of the platforms.

According to known Billbil-kun, WWE 2K26 will launch on Friday, March 13. According to the report, the game will release on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch 2.

Insider Gaming can corroborate the Switch 2 plans. The game is also expected to be a game-key card, should you get the physical version of the game on the system.

UPDATE 4:27pm ET: Billbil-kun has confirmed to Insider Gaming that it IS coming to PC.

Last Gen and PC Status Remain Unknown

There was no confirmation regarding the game’s availability on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. There was also no mention of WWE 2K26 on PC in Billbil-kun’s report.

Last year’s was available on the platform, but it was treated as a last-gen version of the game, meaning it didn’t include The Island. Also like

As far as what to expect from this year’s game, Insider Gaming was the first outlet to exclusively report that CM Punk will be the feature superstar for the game’s Showcase Mode. WWE 2K26 will also see the addition and return of four match types, including a highly requested return.

The game will also feature the draft in Universe mode, intergender matches in MyFaction, shopping carts to use during matches, an overhauled reversal system, and more.

Pre-orders for WWE 2K26 open on January 30. More information and impressions on the game are expected to come in February after the invite-only creator event.

What are you excited to check out with WWE 2K26 when it releases on March 13? Leave your thoughts down in the comments below, and join the discussion in the official Insider Gaming Discord.

For more news, read about Ubisoft proposing up to 200 job cuts at its Paris headquarters. And for even more Insider Gaming delivered directly to your inbox, sign up for our weekly newsletter.
